body:
The SFA transformer was one of the first things I contributed to the package, it has been in the package in this state for years at this point.

I brought this up in the refactor PR, but it was not addressed.
also, can you esplain why all the tests were passing? The `SFA` transformer is non-compliant, was not excepted from tests, and also did not raise any test breaks - I don't quite understand that.

ok, so do I understand that this is really old legacy code then, before transformers had a consolidated interface?
If it is useful to have dict returns from transformers, should that be another return type?

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1365

We provide an option to return a dataframe instead, which is used for tests. This is not the ideal output datatype, however. The output is very sparse, so dictionaries are ideal.
There are 200 comments in that PR so it was probably just washed away in the tide of feedback, but having a return types for dictionaries or a similar structure would be nice.

The issue with the transformer's output is that there are possibly hundreds of thousands of potential attributes depending on the parameters, of which only a few will have non-0 values for each series. 

You could return a dataframe containing only that attributes which appear for all cases, which the previously mentioned option does, but then it becomes very difficult to compare two sets of data separately transformed.

> The issue with the transformer's output is that there are possibly hundreds of thousands of potential attributes depending on the parameters, of which only a few will have non-0 values for each series.
> 
> You could return a dataframe containing only that attributes which appear for all cases, which the previously mentioned option does, but then it becomes very difficult to compare two sets of data separately transformed.

And as far as I remember, the code became very slow when constantly converting between dicts and DataFrames. A dict as an input to a DataFrame will essentially create a single column for each entry in the dict. Given that the Bag of Patterns representatio has potentially thousands of words this was way too slow.

issue.title: [ENH] new table mtypes: `pd.Series` based, `list` of `dict` (as used in bag of words transformers)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR introduces two new mtypes for the `Table` scitype:
* a `pandas.Series` based mtype, `pd_Series_Table`, which has less conditions on the type than for time series (e.g., no ordered indices needed). This is being used in various components of classifiers, where `y` is a `pandas.Series` but without ordered time index.
* `list_of_dict`, which is a `list` of `dict` with the condition that all entries are primitive (`str`, `int`, or `float`). This is currently returned by bag of words type transformers, see discussion in #2064. Introduction of this type would make those transformers interface compliant.

FYI @patrickzib, @MatthewMiddlehurst

rename.from: [BUG] The `SFA` "transformer" does not comply with any transformer interface
rename.to: [BUG] `SFA` transformer does not comply with any transformer interface since it returns list of dict

body: ok, @MatthewMiddlehurst, @patrickzib, I updated the issue description at the top with the result of our discussions, have a look whether that captures it correctly.

rename.from: [BUG] `SFA` transformer does not comply with any transformer interface since it returns list of dict
rename.to: [BUG] `SFA` transformer does not comply with transformer interface since it returns unsupported format, list of dict

body: Good description of the issue and surrounding discussions.
We´ve added the `list_of_dict` mtype for `Table` to the registry, h ence SFA is now interface compliant (via interface extension)
